intro: Alyssum transsilvanicum, commonly known as Transylvanian alyssum, is a flowering plant native to Central and Eastern Europe. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes many other flowering plants with small, four-petaled flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 20–40 cm and produces clusters of fragrant, white or pale yellow flowers. Its leaves are alternate, ovate, and covered in fine hairs, while its roots are fibrous and adapted to rocky or sandy soils. Alyssum transsilvanicum is often found in meadows and along forest edges, where it thrives in full sun to partial shade.
